did.abstract: A student guidance program was established at Indiana University in the fall of 1939 to help incoming students adjust to college life. Herman T. Briscoe served as the director of the department during its short existence, as in 1942 the program and its responsibilities were replaced by the Junior Division. Collection consists of correspondence, budget files, reports, and the director's committee files. Prominent in the collection are lists of faculty advisors and correspondence regarding the advisory services.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Select files closed to researchers. These files are marked RESTRICTED in the finding aid.

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: Indiana University created the Student Guidance Office in September 1939 to assist incoming freshmen and new upperclassmen to adjust to Indiana University. This action was taken in response to the recommendations made by the Self-Survey Committee which was investigating the administrative structure of the University. According to this committee, there was a need for an office to help prepare high school students for the transition to university life and academic standards.

A major duties of the Student Guidance Office was to provide students with faculty advisors and counsellors. It gave freshman their first introduction to Indiana University by coordinating the freshman orientation programs. The office also conducted testing services to match students with the appropriate class level and established clinics to help students in speech, studying, and reading.

The Student Guidance Office existed for only three years. After 1942 it was replaced by the Junior Division (later renamed University Division) which was a department designed to assist all students regardless of the division or school in which they were enrolled.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into a single series, Administrative files, arranged alphabetically

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Consists of correspondence, budget files, reports, and the director's committee files. Prominent in the collection are lists of faculty advisors and correspondence regarding the advisory services.

The Student Guidance records contain the files of its only director, Herman T. Briscoe. The files document the activities of the office for 1939-1940 and 1941-1942, complete with administrative data such as budget information and material for reports. The records consist of one series of administrative files arranged alphabetically by subject within each academic year.

Foremost among the contents are lists of faculty advisors and correspondence regarding the advisory services. Related to the records on faculty advisors are the files concerning guidance assistants and counsellors of students. The records also document additional tasks undertaken by the Student Guidance Office such as providing freshman orientation programs, a speech clinic, a reading clinic, a study clinic, and a testing office. Access to two files concerning the evaluation of students has been restricted. Permission to use these files must be obtained from the University Archivist.

Also present are files related to Briscoe's activity on four university committees: Athletics, Dormitory, Student Health, and Surplus. His membership on these committees related directly to his role as the Director of the Student Guidance Office. These committees made policy and personnel decisions which affected the status of student life at Indiana University.
